docs.snippet: FOR the third time in less than four years, Latin America has been riveted by the spectacle of a sitting president being subjected to a Watergate-style investigation that could lead to his impeachment. This time the spotlight is on  Ernesto Samper...
docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the third time in less than four years, Latin America has been riveted by the spectacle of a sitting president being subjected to a Watergate-style investigation that could lead to his impeachment. This time the spotlight is on Ernesto Samper Pizano, President of Colombia, implicated by tape recordings and the testimony of former aides as the knowing beneficiary of $6 million in campaign donations from the Cali cocaine cartel. It is still much too early to tell whether Mr. Samper can survive the scandal, or whether, like Fernando Collor de Melo of Brazil and Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, he will eventually have to resign. But in any case, as the Brazilian magazine Veja put it, "a strange epidemic seems to be devastating the presidential palaces of Latin America" lately: Ecuador's Vice President resigned and fled the country this month because of a corruption investigation; Peru and Guatemala are seeking the extradition of former presidents to face criminal charges, and former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico has had to take refuge in the United States amid inquiries into his tenure.

headline.main: The New Latin Scandals Challenge Democracies

docs.snippet: Just outside the fanfare that surrounded the United Nations with a womb of security on Sunday, the Foreign Minister from the tiny nation of Bhutan sat unnoticed at a booth in a coffee shop at 48th Street and First Avenue. He had a  cup of Lipton tea...
docs.lead_paragraph: Just outside the fanfare that surrounded the United Nations with a womb of security on Sunday, the Foreign Minister from the tiny nation of Bhutan sat unnoticed at a booth in a coffee shop at 48th Street and First Avenue. He had a cup of Lipton tea and no armed guard. Dawa Tsering, the Foreign Minister and the official representative of the world's last remaining Himalayan Buddhist kingdom, said he had not been able to meditate much during the weekend. Because King Jigme Singye Wangchuck, Precious Ruler of the Dragon People, had not made the trip to the 50th anniversary of the United Nations, the 60-year-old official had taken part in all the ceremonies and receptions and handshake lines.

headline.main: A Wistful Little Land Savors World Stage

docs.snippet: FREDDY BARROS stood in the spotlight on the Rye High School gymnasium floor.  Not by himself, but with his parents shouldering him up. Last summer, the 15-year-old Rye freshman dreamed of making the basketball team. His appearance last month came at...
docs.lead_paragraph: FREDDY BARROS stood in the spotlight on the Rye High School gymnasium floor. Not by himself, but with his parents shouldering him up. Last summer, the 15-year-old Rye freshman dreamed of making the basketball team. His appearance last month came at a basketball fund-raiser instead. Freddy has non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a life-threatening tumor affecting the lymph glands. The once shy teen-ager has found the courage to accept the limelight and survive in order to help others.

docs.snippet: In one of its most substantial efforts to open its markets, China said today  that it would cut tariffs next year on more than 4,000 items by an average of at least 30 percent.         China's promise captured the spotlight on a day in which leaders...
docs.lead_paragraph: In one of its most substantial efforts to open its markets, China said today that it would cut tariffs next year on more than 4,000 items by an average of at least 30 percent. China's promise captured the spotlight on a day in which leaders of 18 Pacific Rim nations endorsed a blueprint to achieve free trade in their vast region by the year 2020 using what they described as a new and unique voluntary approach.

headline.main: In a Move to Open Its Markets, China Pledges to Cut Tariffs on 4,000Items Next Year

docs.snippet: The Federal Aviation Administration's continuing assessment of the aviation safety standards of other countries has added five nations to its list of those  that do not meet international requirements. The countries -- Ecuador, Israel, Jordan, Peru...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration's continuing assessment of the aviation safety standards of other countries has added five nations to its list of those that do not meet international requirements. The countries -- Ecuador, Israel, Jordan, Peru and Venezuela -- got "conditional" ratings in the F.A.A.'s study of countries with airlines that fly to the United States. This means that airlines from these countries may continue limited operations into the United States, under more intense F.A.A. surveillance, while efforts continue to improve safety standards. The aviation agency's most recent report, on Nov. 2, said that five other countries -- Australia, Hungary, New Zealand, Romania and Western Samoa -- met the international standards set by the International Civil Aviation Organization, a United Nations agency. The F.A.A. judges on world standards, which are less stringent than the F.A.A.'s, which apply to United States airlines.

headline.main: Travel Advisory;F.A.A. Limits Rights Of 5 Foreign Countries

docs.snippet: Leaders of the European Union offered new hope today to countries in Eastern  Europe that their admission to the union and its single market would come sooner rather than later.         Ending a two-day summit meeting here, the 15 leaders agreed to...
docs.lead_paragraph: Leaders of the European Union offered new hope today to countries in Eastern Europe that their admission to the union and its single market would come sooner rather than later. Ending a two-day summit meeting here, the 15 leaders agreed to begin formal negotiations with 10 Eastern European countries, as well as Malta and Cyprus, by the end of 1997.

headline.main: European Union Offers Timetable for Talks With Applicants
